answers.author: Robert Hanna
answers.text:
I don't think anybody has any credible knowledge on the healthcare reform legislation passed earlier this year. There are far too many "as determined by (insert federal agency here)  " to have any definitives. That's one of the reasons I believe the major overhaul doesn't become effective until 2014. I agree the language in the legislation says that health benefits must be reported on a W-2 or a 1099 (memory is merky), but it doesn't say it is taxable income. The IRS is one of the responsible agencies for insuring compliance with the healthcare reform legislation. I think people are jumping to the conclusion it will become a taxable benefit. It could just be the vehicle they are using for reporting coverage requirements. The jury is still out on this and probbaly will be for at least one or more years. This doesn't really answer your question, but I couldn't resist adding my two cents. It is probably all it is worth too!
